history.content: EE is a little more difficult to generalize since it covers a wide variety of fields, many of which require wildly different skill sets. However, if there's one subject every EE needs (though one does not need to love it), it is EE 120, signals/systems- even a device physicist will find such information useful.  EE 105 is useful as an introduction or preview to circuits and device physics, and also gives insight into the constraints physics (or circuits) places on systems; for instance its relatively easy for a communications engineer to demonstrate 4096-QAM on matlab- but it's nearly impossible to actually build a radio that can handle that!  Taking 120 & 105 is a great introduction to the world of electrical engineering, with maybe 147 (great class), MEMS, to cover fabrication/devices/mems.

EE is a little more difficult to generalize since it covers a wide variety of fields. However, if there's one subject every EE needs (though one does not need to love it), it is EE 120, signals/systems- even a device physicist will find such information useful.  EE 105 is useful as an introduction or preview to circuits and device physics, and also gives insight into the constraints physics (or circuits) places on systems; for instance its relatively easy for a communications engineer to demonstrate 4096-QAM on matlab- but it's nearly impossible to actually build a radio that can handle that!  Taking 120 & 105 is a great introduction to the world of electrical engineering, with maybe 147 (great class), MEMS, to cover fabrication/devices/mems.

children.subject: Rohit's answer above is great, although I'd argue that EECS 151 might be more relevant to the typical CS major than EE 105, considering that programmers are far more likely to encounter FPGAs than they are to run into amplifiers or other similar analog circuits. That being said, 105 is broader in scope than 151 and strictly more manageable. 151's project is frankly brutal and, conceptually, while it isn't the hardest, it certainly isn't easy either -- after all, 151 was formed from the merger of CS 150 and EE 141, which remain distinct classes at many universities. As an additional note, if you are at all interested in computer architecture, absolutely take 151 (and CS 152 as well).
I tried looking at the syllabus, but it only gave vague information about what you do in the class. Could you give some detail about the lecture material + labs you do?

EECS 149 is great for better understanding how devices interact with the real world. You get an excellent mix of both hardware and software and build really cool devices that are applicable to everyday electronics. e.g. Embedded systems are crucial to any mobile or wireless devices you can think of

history.content:
As title. Analogous to 170 (and 162 etc) being the core essential CS courses, what are the most essential EE courses? As a CS major, I want to learn some EE knowledge before I graduate, since this may be the time in my life that is most close to EE... I am considering EE 105 and 120 being the most essential ones, are there any other opinions, or are there any other classes that is worth taking also? (Besides 126 and 127 , which I will definitely take).

Thank you so much!
history.subject: What are the most essential upper div EE courses?
